thread.title: Ellwood City averts strike with tentative agreement
thread.title_full: Ellwood City averts strike with tentative agreement

author: epoole@ellwoodcityledger.com(Eric Poole)
title: Ellwood City averts strike with tentative agreement
text:
Ellwood City averts strike with tentative agreement By Eric Poole epoole@ellwoodcityledger.com EllwoodCityLedger.com | 0 comments 
ELLWOOD CITY -- Heading into Monday night's last-ditch session to negotiate a new contract for teachers in the Ellwood City Area School District, school board Vice President LeRoy Cortez said both sides were determined to avoid a strike scheduled to begin Tuesday. 
"We're prepared to do what we have to do," he said. 
Those words turned out to be informed, if not prophetic. After less than three hours of talks Monday night, district negotiators and the teachers union reached a tentative agreement to avoid what would have been the first strike in district history. 
District parents were informed of the agreement at 9 p.m., three hours after the negotiations session began, by automated phone call from Superintendent Joe Mancini. 
Terms of the tentative agreement were unavailable Monday night. 
Students had classes as scheduled Monday. A strike would have begun with cancellation of classes Tuesday morning. 
Monday's session came after 12 hours of negotiations on Oct. 7 and 8 that ended without an agreement. After a three-hour session Oct. 7, the teachers association announced Oct. 8 its intention to strike Tuesday if no contract agreement was reached. 
The union, which represents 130 teachers, will have the opportunity to ratify the agreement, as will the school board, before the contract becomes final. 
District teachers have been working since the beginning of this school year without a contract, after the previous pact expired June 30. 
Monday's tentative agreement marks what might have been the closest the district has come to striking. In 2006, the two sides reached a tentative agreement about 5 a.m. on Friday, May 5, after teachers announced their intention to walk out the following Monday.
